head.title: A House of Books, Each One a Memory

hedline.hl1: A House of Books, Each One a Memory

abstract.p: Nancy Cowan Weisman letter on John Updike's June 18 article cites emotional importance of family's book collection; drawing

block.p: ''Books Unbound, Life Unraveled,'' by John Updike (Op-Ed, June 18), brought to mind the day I packed up my father's apartment after his death in 1994.

''Books Unbound, Life Unraveled,'' by John Updike (Op-Ed, June 18), brought to mind the day I packed up my father's apartment after his death in 1994.

My childhood bedroom was now a library, and I painstakingly and lovingly went through each book, unable to discard any that were not completely falling apart. A friend I've had since high school helped me and shared the memories.
I found my grandparents' books, my uncle's books, New York Public Library books circa 1920, my father's high school and college textbooks, my mother's best friend's poetry and so on.
I packed them all up and sent them to Atlanta, where they are now the furniture of our library, which is one of my children's previous bedrooms and is a guest room for children and grandchildren.
A heritage by Microsoft? I think not.
